headline: Tres Leches Cake with Strawberries
description: This tres leches cake from chef Soledad Correa has the right balance of sweetness. It contains just a hint of cinnamon and is beautifully complemented by the sweet-tart strawberries.

video.description: Many versions of this dessert, made by soaking sponge cake in condensed milk, evaporated milk and cream, are too sweet and wet. This one from chef Soledad Correa of Casa Silva is perfect, with just a hint of cinnamon.
video.name: Tres Leches Cake with Strawberries

name: Tres Leches Cake with Strawberries
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup whole milk, at room temperature
Thinly sliced mint leaves, for serving

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350Â°F. Lightly butter a 9- x 13-inch glass or ceramic baking dish. Place flour, baking powder, and salt in a medium bowl and whisk together.
In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with paddle, beat eggs with sugar and 1 teaspoon of the vanilla at medium-high speed until very light and fluffy, about 10 minutes.
Add half of the flour mixture and mix at low speed until just incorporated. Gradually add whole milk, then mix in remaining flour mixture.
Pour batter into prepared baking dish and bake until center of cake springs back to the touch, 25 to 30 minutes.
Transfer baking dish to a rack and let cake cool for at least 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, whisk cream with evaporated milk, cinnamon stick, and cloves in a medium saucepan over moderately high heat; bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 3 minutes. Remove from heat, cover, and let steep for 10 minutes.
Combine condensed milk with remaining 1 teaspoon of vanilla and the ground cinnamon in a heatproof bowl.
Strain steeped cream mixture into condensed milk and stir to combine. Let cool for 20 minutes.
Using a fork, poke holes all over cooled cake. Gradually pour milk mixture over entire cake. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Gently toss strawberries with sugar in a bowl. Let stand at room temperature for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally to dissolve sugar.
Cut cake and serve with strawberries, whipped cream, and mint.

review.reviewBody: Anyone that says this recipe has too much liquid is doing it wrong. This is hands down the best recipe out there exactly as written! Perfection

Made this recipe for a Mexican themed dinner at church to compliment the meal. As a few other comments, I will have to agree, this recipe makes a very dense cake and even with what I was concerned to be too much milk for the topping, it actually didnt offer enough in the end. The cake turned out like the ones I do not like about cakes that alot of resturants serve. This cake turned out a little too dry and tasted like it was days old when it was only made last night. Another recipe calls to seperate the yolks and whites. I believe I will try this next time. I used coconut condensed milk for a richer flavor and feel it did help as well as doubled the vanilla and used vanilla bean paste. I feel it makes all my recipes taste so much better. All in all, this was a tasty cake.

My new favourite cake recipe, very rich but also tastes very refreshing chilled with the whipped cream and strawberries. I followed the instructions exactly (except I am in the UK so used plain flour), I did not separate eggs like some have suggested, and it come out nicely risen and the amount of liquid left it perfectly moist and oozy, not sopping. Good after 1 day, even better after 2.

This is our go to desert for friends and family who like creamy sweet treats. The recipe works EXACTLY as written. You do need to beat the eggs in a stand up mixer for 10 minutes until very thick and fluffy. Donât skip this step. It is delicious and very much worth the wait!

Directions are missing a really important detail: you have to separate the egg whites from the yolk and whisk the egg whites (with no sugar added). The egg whites can be mixed with the flour mixture, sugar and milk, and then you gently fold the egg whites in. The entire point is for the whipped whites to form the light fluffy body of the cake, and if you go by the posted directions, it won't rise. It will be shallow and dense and effectively inedible. I made two versions of this specifically because I saw the directions and have made tres leches before (wanted to try some different recipes) and that egg white tip is a consistent requirement for a proper cake. I recommend doing 1 cup flour, 5 eggs with the whites and yolks separate (yolks whipped into a consistency where you can make a peak that isn't stiff but holds its shape), 2/3 cup of sugar, 1.5 teaspoons baking powder, 1/3 cup of milk, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Vanilla in this recipe is fine, I actually prefer more. The spiced milk mixture included on this recipe is also good.

3 stars because it tastes good. Too much liquid resulting in a floating cake. If I wanted sweet soup, I wouldn't have searched for a cake recipe... I also don't appreciate the creator of the recipe not responding to those with questions or criticism. It's disrespectful & shows lack of professionalism. Save your money, find a different recipe.

Delish! I made it exactly as written except for the cinnamon and cloves, and I used cake flour instead of all-purpose. I wasn't sure my family would like the spice so I left it out. It was divine and the exact right amount of milks to the cake. I didn't use a fork, but the end of a beater from my hand mixer (so a little smaller than a pencil, but bigger than fork holes). I wanted to make sure it soaked in. When I poured on the milk I poured it directly into all the holes first until they filled, then poured it all around. I've dished out several servings and there's not much left in the pan, so it all soaked in beautifully and the cake is milky and delicious. When I make it again I think I'll add a little more vanilla to the milk and the cake batter. So yummy!

This recipe was absolutely delicious. I highly recommend letting the cake marinate over night. I had some after 5 hours and then another portion after dinner 24 hours later and it tasted like a different cake...a perfect cake.
